text: +1 to they don’t need your permission. If it’s stipulated in your contract that the work you produce for this company while you work for them is theirs by default (which is usually the case)—they don’t need to ask you. But it would have been a nice gesture for them to make this clear from the beginning

text:
What <@U03ATNPT8H1> said. My decision to join Udemy after getting laid off at Eventbrite was rooted in my passion on continuous learning. Going to Hopin may seem like a choice rooted in “sticking with what you know” but was actually more because I would be able to do my best work (vs continue following an outdated template). In fact, when Hopin reached out to me, I was deciding between two different offers in completely new industries (data/analytics and literature/publishing) that were also going to allow me to do my best work.

TL;DR: If you’re passionate or interested in the industry AND you’ll get to do your best work, it doesn’t matter IMO.

TL;DR: If you’re passionate or interested in the industry AND you’ll get to do your best work, it doesn’t matter IMO.

text:
It's really normal in my industry (SaaS/Tech). For example, if I write on social media, I'll probably put it in my SMM's name, SEO in our Head of SEO's name, etc. It comes with more authority, although I'm pretty well-versed on these topics as well. If it's an article I think would be good for my portfolio, I save it for later. It's just as display, so I can show it off proudly, but there's not exactly a way to prove it.

That said, I'm also at a point in my career where I don't really _need_ my name attached to work. If you're just getting started or building your name in your industry, I can absolutely see why it would matter and feeling a bit upset about it.

I would talk to your team and ask about which pieces should be attached to your name and what the policy is moving forward. If you're ghost writing, I 100% agree with the person above that you should be paid more for that.

my name attached to work. If you're just getting started or building your name in your industry, I can absolutely see why it would matter and feeling a bit upset about it.
